newsitem.title: USA: Canada spot natgas edges higher on colder weather.
newsitem.headline: Canada spot natgas edges higher on colder weather.

text.p: Canadian spot natural gas prices edged higher Monday, lifted by forecasts for cooler temperatures, market sources said.
At the AECO storage hub, prices gained another six cents to C$1.42-1.44 per gigajoule (GJ), as cold weather in western Canada continued to drain supplies.
"A lot of people are packing their accounts for tomorrow because it's supposed to get colder," one Calgary-based trader said.

Despite milder weather over the weekend, temperatures in Calgary are forecast to reach highs of only -5 to -6 degrees Celsius Tuesday, with the cold expected to continue over the next few days, traders said.
In response to the stronger day market, summer AECO prices climbed to C$1.42-1.45 per GJ. April bids and offers widened to C$1.42-1.46, though no deals were reported done.

At Sumas, Wash., prices were unchanged at $1.15-1.20 per million British thermal units (mmBtu) in light trade. Below-normal temperatures coupled with a plentiful hydroelectric supply left the market in a standstill, traders said.
Also in anticipation of colder weather as the week progresses, Niagara prices were up four cents to $2.09-2.14 per mmBtu.
